occurrences.line_text: She by creation was, till she did fall;
By riches and vnrighteous reward,
Some by close shouldring, some by flatteree;
Some by close shouldring, some by flatteree;
And all by wrong wayes for themselues prepard.
Through griesly shadowes by a beaten path,
One cursed creature, he by chaunce espide,
And most vniust, that by vnrighteous
Sir Guyon laid in swowne is by
By further search had passage found elsewhere,
That bad him come in haste. He by and by
That bad him come in haste. He by and by
Gaz'd after him, as fowle escapt by flight;
The worth of all men by their end esteeme,
Th'enchaunter by his armes and amenaunce,
And to those brethren said, Rise rise by liue,
Which Merlin made by his almightie art
Ne euer may be vsed by his fone,
By this that straunger knight in presence came,
Or did he fall by treason, or by fight?
Or did he fall by treason, or by fight?
And by your powre protect his feeble cace.
Therefore by Termagaunt thou shalt be dead.
And fowly said, By Mahoune, cursed thiefe,
That no'te auoyded be by earthly skill or powre.
That may not hope by flight to scape aliue,
By this Sir Guyon from his traunce awakt,
Had lost, he by him spide, right glad he grew,
My Lord, my liege, by whose most gratious ayd
Are not all knights by oath bound, to withstond
Oppressours powre by armes and puissant hond?
By faithfull seruice, and meet amenance,
But by your wondrous worth and warlike feat
Proportioned equally by seuen and nine;
The one before, by which all in did pas,
By them as Alma passed with her guestes,
Who passing by, forth led her guestes anone
But to delay the heat, least by mischaunce
There added was by goodly ordinaunce,
Till by a conduit pipe it thence were brought:
By secret wayes, that none might it espy,
The Prince by chaunce did on a Lady light,
That by well doing sought to honour to aspire.
Faire Damzell, seemeth, by your troubled cheare,
Ascending by ten steps of Alablaster wrought.
From which young Hectors bloud by cruell Greekes was spilt.
By Phoebus doome, the wisest thought aliue,
Might be compar'd to these by many parts:
By whose aduise old Priams cittie fell,
Some daily seene, and knowen by their names,
That hight Phantastes by his nature trew;
That mad or foolish seemd: one by his vew
And that old man Eumnestes, by their propertis.
By which all earthly Princes she doth farre surmount.
By sea to haue bene fro[m] the Celticke mayn-land brought.
By hunting and by spoiling liued then;
By hunting and by spoiling liued then;
Into this land by chaunce haue driuen bene,
Driuen by fatall error, here arriu'd,
In meed of these great conquests by them got,
Begotten by her kingly Paramoure,
His sonne king Leill by fathers labour long,
And twixt them shayrd his realme by equall lots:
In which he dyde, made ripe for death by eld,
By such, as claymd themselues Brutes rightfull haires,
By which he freed the Traueilers high way,
By strength was wielded without pollicie;
All which successiuely by turnes did raine;
Till by his death he it recouered;
By dew successe, and all their Nephewes late,
Till aged Hely by dew heritage it gaynd.
By which he lyes entombed solemnly.
Was by the people chosen in their sted,
So by him Caesar got the victory,
In which the king was by a Treachetour
Both in his armes, and crowne, and by that draught
By reason that the Captaines on her side,
Corrupted by Paulinus, from her sweru'd:
But shortly was by Coyll in battell slaine:
And it vsurped by vnrighteous doome:
But he his title iustifide by might,
Who soone by meanes thereof the Empire wan,
Till murdred by the friends of Gratian;
Was by Maximian lately led away,
Till by consent of Commons and of Peares,
By meanes whereof, their vncle Vortigere
But by the helpe of Vortimere his sonne,
By this the sonnes of Constantine, which fled,
Who flying from his guilt, by them was slaine,
So now entombed lyes at Stoneheng by the heath.
His worke, for which he was by Ioue depriued
He built by art vpon the glassy See
Him to succeede therein, by his last will:
To see a cruell fight doen by the Prince this day.
That is each thing, by which the eyes may fault:
For by those vgly formes weren pourtrayd,
Which by the ransack of that peece they should attaine.
(As wonts the Tartar by the Caspian lake,
And led him to the Castle by the beaten way.
And all the while his wounds were dressing, by him stayd.
Guyon, by Palmers gouernance,
They passing by, that griesly mouth did see,
By these rent reliques, speaking their ill plights?
In the wide sea, they needes must passen by,
By whom a litle skippet floting did appeare.
But by the way, there is a great Quicksand,
But by the checked waue they did descry
It plaine, and by the sea discoloured:
They passing by, a goodly Ship did see,
Did couet, as they passed by that way,
By that same wicked witch, to worke vs dreed,
A seemely Maiden, sitting by the shore,
So now to Guyon, as he passed by,
Such as by nature men abhorre and hate,
But th'other by his boate behind did stay.
A place pickt out by choice of best aliue,
That natures worke by art can imitate:
By which the mightiest things efforced bin:
And strowed round about, and by his side
So did he eke Sir Guyon passing by:
All passers by, to tast their lushious wine,
So made by art, to beautifie the rest,
Whom passing by she happened to meet:
The trembling groues, the Christall running by;
As Guyon hapned by the same to wend,
Her plong, as ouer maistered by might,
The young man sleeping by her, seemd to bee
That had an hog beene late, hight Grille by name,
If pourtrayd it might be by any liuing art.
Which by that new rencounter he should reare:
For by his mightie Science he had seene
By such good meanes he him discounselled,
In hope her to attaine by hooke or crooke,
These sixe would me enforce by oddes of might,
To weene your wrong by force to iustifie:
Ne may loue be compeld by maisterie;
Or else with vs by dint of sword approue,
The fourth was by that other knight dismayd,
Which by her owne law to your lot doth light,
(For so that Castle hight by commune name)
Or bathe him in a fountaine by some couert glade.
And by his side the Goddesse groueling
The first of them by name Gardante hight,
Who by self-feeling of her feeble sexe,
And by long triall of the inward griefe,
By this th'eternall lampes, wherewith high Ioue
And by her side her selfe she softly layd,
Where feeling one close couched by her side,
But by ensample of the last dayes losse,
The wondrous myrrhour, by which she
But by record of antique times I find,
She trauelling with Guyon by the way,
By sea, by land, where so they may be met,
By sea, by land, where so they may be met,
Far fro my natiue soyle, that is by name
For hardy thing it is, to weene by might,
Tell me some markes, by which he may appeare,
By strange occasion she did him behold,
By his deepe science, and hell-dreaded might,
Ybuilded all of glasse, by Magicke powre,
By knowen signes and passions, which I see,
Then I auow by this most sacred head
May learned be by cyphers, or by Magicke might.
May learned be by cyphers, or by Magicke might.
Then I auow to thee, by wrong or right
And set her by to watch, and set her by to weepe.
And set her by to watch, and set her by to weepe.
That well can witnesse, who by triall it does proue.
Which long hath waited by the Stygian strond.
Till that by dew degrees and long pretence,
And by what meanes his loue might best be wrought:
To Maridunum, that is now by chaunge
For he by words could call out of the sky
By false illusion of a guilefull Spright,
Who was the Lord of Mathrauall by right,
And to her said, Beldame, by that ye tell,
Doth by her blushing tell, that she did lye
Most noble Virgin, that by fatall lore
And do by all dew meanes thy destiny fulfill.
And whilome by false Faries stolne away,
But that he by an Elfe was gotten of a Fay.
Too rathe cut off by practise criminall
Nor so fowle outrage doen by liuing men:
With heauenly powre, and by Angels reskewd,
When the full time prefixt by destiny,
Shalbe by vision staid from his intent:
Which Bladud made by Magick art of yore,
Both speare she tooke, and shield, which hong by it:
Where be the braue atchieuements doen by some?
By which the Redcrosse knight did earst display
By this forbidden way in my despight,
Ne doest by others death ensample take,
And through his mayled hauberque, by mischaunce
As he by chaunce did wander that same way,
Was taken with her loue, and by her closely lay.
Did get through great aduentures by him donne:
For neuer man he suffred by that same
One day of Proteus by his mightie spell,
Or weene by warning to auoyd his fate?
Amongst her watry sisters by a pond,
They were all taught by Triton, to obay
In leaches craft, by great Appolloes lore,
Where by the grim floud of Cocytus slow
But he sets nought at all by Florimell:
By your good counsell, or bold hardiment,
But by the way he greatly gan complaine
And bold, as euer Squire that waited by knights side.
And now by fortune it was ouerflowne:
By that same way they knew that Squire vnknowne
For by no meanes the high banke he could sease,
By tract of bloud, which she had freshly seene,
By the great persue, which she there perceau'd,
And feeling by his pulses beating rife,
By this he had sweete life recur'd againe,
And gifts of heauenly grace he by him spide,
By this her Damzels, which the former chace
Thy life she saued by her gracious deed,
Of euery thing consumes, and calcineth by art.
The daughter of Amphisa, who by race
By what straunge accident faire Chrysogone
Doe life conceiue and quickned are by kynd:
By Stygian lake I vow, whose sad annoy
But well I wote by tryall, that this same
And called is by her lost louers name,
The Gardin of Adonis, farre renowmd by fame.
By which both in and out men moten pas;
Till they againe returne backe by the hinder gate.
Which first was spoken by th'Almightie lord,
Set by it selfe, and ranckt in comely rew:
By course of kind, and by occasion;
By course of kind, and by occasion;
There was a pleasant arbour, not by art,
By her hid from the world, and from the skill
And by succession made perpetuall,
But shewd by outward signes, that dread her sence did daze.
With silly Virgin by aduenture brought
And by what accident she there arriued:
Might by the witch or by her sonne compast:
Might by the witch or by her sonne compast:
And by her deuilish arts thought to preuaile,
Sought by all meanes his dolour to prolong,
And crost the nearest way, by which he cast
Her to encounter, ere she passed by:
By this the good Sir Satyrane gan wake
And drunke with bloud of men, slaine by his might,
I glad by any meanes her grace to gaine,
Whom I in countrey cottage found by chaunce;
Who wrongd by Carle by Proteus sau'd,
Who wrongd by Carle by Proteus sau'd,
Is sought by Paridell.
Now when the Beast, which by her wicked art
By their aduise, and her owne wicked wit,
By errant Sprights, but from all men conceald:
There them by chaunce encountred on the way
Driuen to great distresse by Fortune straunge,
Both by the burning hart, which on his brest
He bare, and by the colours in his crest,
And knighthood fowle defaced by a faithlesse knight.
Offend the good: for good by paragone
Ne all are shamed by the fault of one;
The man by gentle meanes, to let vs in,
Then if all fayle, we will by force it win,
To dry them selues by Vulcanes flaming light,
From top of Hemus, by him heaped hye;
His inward griefe, by meanes to him well knowne,
And by the dauncing bubbles did diuine,
By such close signes they secret way did make
By their faire handling, put into Malbeccoes cape.
Purpose was moued by that gentle Dame,
Most famous Worthy of the world, by whome
Brought vnto balefull ruine, was by name
That was by him cald Paros, which before
And built Nausicle by the Pontick shore,
From whom I Paridell by kin descend;
In forreine landes, and all which passen by,
And Hygate made the meare thereof by West,
And Ouert gate by North: that is the bound
That Albion had conquered first by warlike feat.
At last by fatall course they driuen were
Which by the houres he measured, besought
By which he feareth euill happen may:
So th'euill thinkes by watching to preuent;
All that is by the working of thy Deitee.
To seeke her endlong, both by sea and lond.
One day, as he forpassed by the plaine
For I vnwares this way by fortune straid,
Then now, that noble succour is thee by,
By treacherous deceipt did me depriue;
By Sanglamort my sword, whose deadly dent
As on aduenture by the way he past:
And now by fortune was arriued here,
That it was he, which by her side did dwell,
And would haue wakt the Satyre by her syde;
And by no meanes would to his will be wonne,
By which there lay a knight all wallowed
Vpon the grassy ground, and by him neare
By strong enchauntments and blacke Magicke leare,
But yet by torture he would her constraine
Ne may by liuing meanes be thence relest:
This fire be quencht by any wit or might,
Ne yet by any meanes remou'd away,
As seemed by their semblaunt did entreat;
And richlier by many partes arayd:
By any ridling skill, or commune wit.
By liuely actions he gan bewray
And passing by, his name discouered,
That by his gate might easily appeare;
The other cleped Cruelty by name:
Cald by strong charmes out of eternall night,
Vnto a brasen pillour, by the which she stands.
Had not the Lady, which by him stood bound,
Which I your vassall, by your prowesse freed,
By which fraile youth is oft to follie led,
Deawd with ambrosiall kisses, by thee gotten
By way of sport, as oft in maskes is knowen,
That well she wist not what by them to gesse,
And much the more, by that he lately wrought,
That fairest Amoret was his by right,
And ech of them had ryding by his side
Hard by the gates of hell her dwelling is,
And by infernall furies nourished,
That by her monstrous shape might easily be red.
She was become, by chaunge of her estate,
By that the louely paire drew nigh to hond:
Yet mindfull how he late by one was feld,
To be Sir Scudamour, by that he bore
And eke because his loue he wonne by right:
False faitour Scudamour, that hast by slight
This day, to wreake the dammage by thee donne:
An hideous storme, is by the Northerne blast
All manie nights, and manie by in place,
Albee vntrue she wist them by assay.
By thousand furies, and from thence out throwen
And set it all on fire by force vnknowen,
That by themselues vnto themselues is wrought,
That had a goodly Ladie by his side,
By meanes whereof he hath him lightly ouerborne.
And by his false allurements wylie draft
By sundry meanes thereto she prickt him forth,
The open wrongs, thou doest me day by day;
By great aduenture trauelled that way;
And both of old well knowing by their names,
And them coniur'd by some well knowen token,
Weend as he said, by that her outward grace,
Are quite deuourd, and brought to nought by little bits?
They by consent should chose the stoutest three,
Conceiued by a ring, which she him sent,
And yet vncertaine by such outward sight,
Which she by art could vse vnto her will,
Did by great fortune get of her the sight;
As she sate carelesse by a cristall flood,
Their safetie, least by searching daungers new,
By wondrous skill, and many hidden wayes,
By griesly Lachesis was spun with paine,
She them saluting, there by them sate still,
To them ordained by eternall fate.
That they auoyded were, and vainely by did slyde.
By Priamond, that with vnluckie glaunce,
Where fast infixed, whilest he sought by slight
Haue by good fortune found some beasts fresh spoyle,
Till hauing often by him stricken beene,
Such as the maker selfe could best by art deuize.
And well instructed by the Fay her mother,
Who vnderstanding by her mightie art,
And by the tailes together firmely bound,
Deuized by the Gods, for to asswage
Are by the Gods to drinck thereof assynd;
Described by that famous Tuscane penne:
At last arriuing by the listes side,
By all that vnto them was deare, did them beseeke.
And wise Cambina taking by her side
That well (me seemes) appeares, by that of late
As als by this, that now a new debate
The which by course befals me here to tell:
And rather stird by his discordfull Dame,
Sith each of them his Ladie had him by,
Now falne into their fellowship by chance,
Which Blandamour had riding by his side:
And proffer made by force her to reprize:
That who so winnes her, may her haue by right:
And now by this, Sir Satyrane abraid,
By that the gloomy euening on them fell,
Like as a Lion that by chaunce doth fall
As when two greedy Wolues doe breake by force
That by their many wounds, and carelesse harmes,
By shiuered speares, and swords all vnder strowen,
By scattered shields was easie to be showen.
But when they could not learne it by no wize,
By his sole manhood and atchieuement stout
But by his friend himselfe eke soone he fond,
Dame Venus girdle, by her steemed deare,
Was fostered by those Graces, (as they say)
That goodly belt was Cestus hight by name,
And as her life by her esteemed deare.
And now by this their feast all being ended,
There was it iudged by those worthie wights,
Till by mishap he in his foemens hand did light.
To Britomart was giuen by good right;
By view of all the fairest to him brought,
As guilefull Goldsmith that by secret skill,
Then was that golden belt by doome of all
But by no meanes they could it thereto frame.
It yeelded was by them, that iudged it:
Her claym'd, by him in battell wonne long sens:
Some thought from him her to haue reft by might;
That by no reason it might be reuerst,
By which few crooked sallowes grew in ranke:
His name was Care; a blacksmith by his trade,
For by degrees they all were disagreed;
He by no meanes could wished ease obtaine:
And if by fortune any litle nap
When euer he this way shall passe by day or night.
But what is he, by whom ye shamed were?
A stranger knight, sayd he, vnknowne by name,
But knowne by fame, and by an Hebene speare,
But knowne by fame, and by an Hebene speare,
That thus he sharply sayd; Now by my head,
Which that same knight, whom by his launce I read,
And if to that auenge by you decreed
Throwne out by angry Ioue in his vengeance,
That by the swift recourse of flushing blood
Thinking to hide the depth by troubling of the flood.
For louers heauen must passe by sorrowes hell.
But comfort take: for by this heauens light
All being guided by Sir Artegall.
That all so soone as he by wit or art
And by the way she sundry purpose found
True loue and faithfull friendship, she by her did set.
Yet found they none. But by what haplesse fate,
Amoret rapt by greedie lust
By heaping stormes of trouble on them daily more?
And eke in stature higher by a span,
More great then th'eares of Elephants by Indus flood.
With that she heard some one close by her side
Now twenty daies, by which the sonnes of men
Seauen women by him slaine, and eaten clene.
By any Ladies side for Leman to haue laine.
Vnto my choise by no meanes would assent,
Thenceforth I sought by secret meanes to worke
But read to me, by what deuise or wit,
That by his grenning laughter mote farre off be rad.
Doth hast to crosse him by the nearest way,
He by his former combate would not bide,
There she him found by that new louely mate,
For on a day, by fortune as it fell,
Yet weend by secret signes of manlinesse,
Which he obseru'd, by that he him had seene
And eke by that he saw on euery tree,
Which was by him BELPHEBE rightly rad.
And is by Arthure slaine.
Well said the wiseman, now prou'd true by this,
Shee sitting by him as on ground he lay,
By chance he certaine miniments forth drew,
And by his persons secret seemlyhed
Of that same wicked Carle, by Virgins hond;
Himselfe by them on foot, to succour them from feare.
And eke the Doue sate by the Faulcons side,
And vow by Mahoune that he should be slaine.
All which was thus to him declared by that Squire.
And by his strength rule to himselfe did gaine
Whom yet he conquer'd not by bloudie fight,
But by the powre of his infectious sight,
By casting secret flakes of lustfull fire
But by that meanes, which fortune did vnfold,
By her committed be, of speciall grace,
To seeke by flight her fellowship t'eschew,
So on a day as by the flowrie marge
Then lesse (said she) by all the woe I pas,
And well perform'd, as shall appeare by his euent.
All which who list by tryall to assay,
As she had learned readily by rote.
He her vnwares attacht, and captiue held by might.
But saw him sencelesse by the Squire vpstaide,
As if that by one patterne seene somewhere,
The which that tyrant gathered had by wrong
And by the rest did set in sumptuous chaire,
Faire Amoret, whom Fortune by bequest
That all the while he by his side her bore,
By Braggadochio lately was redeemed.
For losse of his deare loue by Neptune hent,
By fortune in that place did chance to light:
That the other litle gained by the lone,
In open turney, and by wrongfull fight
And in that right should by all knights be shielded:
That I too true by triall haue approued:
To winne me honour by some noble gest,
Might be my lucky lot; sith all by lot we hold.
And wall'd by nature gainst inuaders wrong,
But by one way, that passage did prepare.
By all meanes to maintaine that castels ancient rights.
And by good fortune shortly him vnseated.
I knockt, but no man aunswred me by name;
But by no meanes my way I would forslow,
Cast into sundry shapes by wondrous skill,
Crept in by stouping low, or stealing of the kaies.
For all that nature by her mother wit
All which by nature made did nature selfe amaze.
All these together by themselves did sport
Pylades and Orestes by his syde;
Might match with this by many a degree:
